awd_titl_txt: NCA&T ADVANCE Institutional Transformation: Catalyzing Gender, Leadership, and Scholarship Equity through Institutional Change for All
awd_abstract_narration:
ADVANCING STEM Women at Historically Black Institutions: Ensuring the Best STEM Minds Stay at the Table 

North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University will solve a conundrum while transforming itself into an open, transparent community that supports STEM faculty to achieve their best. Research demonstrates how unconscious bias can hold women back from inclusion in the STEM enterprise; NC A&T will help us better understand how gender barriers intersect with racial/ethnicity barriers through its ADVANCE Institutional Transformation award. Dr. Shirley Malcom, former president of AAAS, calls the predicament of STEM women of color "The Double Bind": if it's hard for us to imagine a woman when we hear the word "scientist", it's doubly hard to imagine a woman of color as a scientist. NC A&T will study the factors that lead to the "double bind" and will develop strategies to address the double bind for women at Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), strategies that can also be applied to lower barriers for STEM women of color at historically majority institutions. The strategies NC A&T develops and disseminates will help lower barriers for all STEM women through their findings on how to best mentor STEM faculty at mid-career. 

NC A&T, through its ADVANCE Institutional Transformation award, will not wait to find answers to the double bind: they will provide STEM women faculty novel professional development opportunities, such as developing personal professional development plans with able mentors, and visiting funding agencies in the DC metro area, an opportunity not previously available to an historically teaching-focused institution. As the nation's population becomes increasingly diverse, we want all the best heads at the bench and in the field: NC A&T will ensure that the best minds are not excluded because they don't fit the traditional mold.

por.por_cntn:
In 2014 when NC A&T ADVANCE IT project was funded, women faculty at North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University (NC A&T) were underrepresented in tenured and senior faculty roles within the STEM disciplines which aligned to national data. The NC A&T ADVANCE-IT project was based on an empowerment construct that catalyzes professional gains for women faculty at all levels, but particularly those in the transition from Associate to Full Professor. Our project served as a change agent designed to help catalyze sustainable institutional transformations leading to the enhancement of the research and leadership capabilities of all faculty, especially women, resulting in an increase in their overall professional achievements.  The goals of our project were (1) to catalyze and implement approaches that significantly increase the representation and career advancement of women in STEM and SBS disciplines at North Carolina A&T State University; and (2) to fill knowledge gaps on the empowerment and equity of women in the academy. The empowerment approach, while specifically targeting women in STEM, increased the research and leadership capabilities of all faculty and supported their overall professional achievement, thereby catalyzing sustainable institutional transformations.  Thus, cultivating organizational transformation through psychological and structural empowerment has allowed ADVANCE to foster greater inclusivity of women at all levels of the academy and has positively affected all faculty across the entire campus of NC A&T.  

The intervention activities of our project were based on institutional data, and literature on the empowerment of women and women of color in STEM/SBS disciplines and have been strategically designed to meet the needs of all faculty.  The strategic approaches, of the project, helped to transform the campus climate and culture to one that is intentional about equity, the inclusion and advancement of women as equal contributors to preeminence, and the ultimate advancement of ALL faculty in scholarly pursuits.

 

The success of the NC A&T ADVANCE IT Project can be measured as the change in the number of STEM/SBS women faculty at all ranks, and the change in institutional policies and practices to support an institutional culture of excellence in research and scholarship for all.  

From 2014 - 2022, the NC A&T ADVANCE IT Project generated the following outcomes:

  • Implemented 3 focus areas addressing recruitment; 7 initiatives for retention and advancement; 3 thrust areas for leadership; and 3 initiatives for policy and climate.
  • Institutionalized a Search Committee Certification Program and the systemic collection and reporting of gender of equity data.
  • Implemented the first theater-based implicit bias training at an HBCU (The Perfect Fit and Tenure and Promotion, The Play).
  • Conducted 3 iterations of a climate survey and the results are being used to drive strategic priorities, influence the faculty handbook, and opened the dialogue to foster equitable and inclusive university culture and climate. 
  • Increased a) the total number of women faculty (all ranks and disciplines); b) the total number of STEM women full and assistant professors; c) the number of women in senior level leadership roles.
  • Increased the total number of proposals submitted and grants awarded as well as an increase in tenure and promotion outcomes for all attendees (male and female) who participated in ADVANCE intervention activities. 
  • Supported women to participate in external leadership training across various events including: BRIDGES, HERS Institute, Fielding Leadership Summit, STEM Women of Color Conclave, and PKAL STEM Leadership Institute.
  • Conducted 4 iterations of a formal leadership development training for department chairs and associate deans to enhance essential skills for effective institutional leadership in critical areas. 
  • Disseminated key findings and best practices for addressing the lack of research on the intersectional experiences of WOC in the academy through 4 peer-reviewed publications and 11 presentations at national or regional conferences including ARC Network, ACS national meeting, ADVANCE GSE, SWOC, SERIMAC, PACIFICHEM, STEM gender summit.
  • Established a network and community of faculty, through informal mentoring and coaching, to promote the advancement of teaching, service and research in support of student success.
  • Created the NC A&T Faculty Commons to institutionalize support for faculty development, teaching, and community engagement.
